content.description: Researchers observe that the water with the high <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration has a lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>pH</mi></math> than does the water with the low <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration. The researchers claim that lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> alters the structure of the enzymes of photosynthesis.
content.question: Which of the following most likely explains how a lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> could alter the structure of photosynthetic enzymes?

choices.label: There will not be enough <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions for the ribosome to correctly form peptide bonds between amino acids during synthesis of the enzymes.

There will not be enough <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions for the necessary hydrogen bonds to form in the secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures of the enzymes.

There will be additional <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that can disrupt peptide bonds in the primary structure of the enzymes.

There will be additional <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that can disrupt hydrogen bonds in the secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of the enzymes.

content.answer: There will be additional <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that can disrupt hydrogen bonds in the secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of the enzymes.
